arm_group.description: Infusion of 1L cold crystalloid solution (4°C) over 15 minutes
Best medical treatment following international stroke guidelines

brief_summary.textblock:
Elevated body temperature was shown to be associated with worse outcome in acute stroke
      patients. PreCOOL 1 aims to investigate efficacy, feasibility and safety of prehospital
      cooling with cold infusions in stroke patients.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Suspected stroke

          -  Symptom onset ≤ 7 days

          -  Tympanic temperature ≥ 36.7°C

          -  Informed consent by the patient

          -  Age ≥ 18 years

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Severe cardiac insufficiency (NYHA ≥ III)

          -  New anisocoria, severe nausea, vomiting or headache

          -  High-grade heart valve stenosis or insufficiency

          -  Acute pulmonary embolism

          -  Acute myocardial infarction

          -  Threatening ventricular dysrhythmia

          -  Known hematologic disease with increased risk of thrombosis (e.g. cryoglobulinemia,
             cold agglutinins, sickle cell anemia)

          -  Known vasospastic vascular disorder (e.g. Raynaud's phenomenon or thromboangiitis
             obliterans)

          -  Severe renal insufficiency with reduced diuresis

          -  Pregnancy

intervention.description: Infusion of 1L cold crystalloid solution (4°C) over 15 minutes
intervention.intervention_name: Cold crystalloid infusions, 0.9%NaCl or Ringer's solution

link.description: Heidelberg HYPOthermia 24/7 - Research group, information and contacts

facility.name: Rescue service, Dept. of Anesthesiology, University Hospital Heidelberg

clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial Evaluating Cold Infusions for Prehospital Induction of Cooling in Awake Stroke Patients (PreCOOL 1)

primary_outcome.description: Primary endpoint: Change of tympanic temperature between measurements before prehospital start of cooling an at arrival in the emergency room.
primary_outcome.time_frame: from randomization (prehospital) until arrival in the ER, an expected average of 45min

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Dr. Sven Poli, Consultant Neurologist, Principical Investigator

secondary_outcome.description: Secondary efficacy endpoint: Proportion of patients having a oral temperature between 36 and 37.1°C at arrival in the ER.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: single measurement at arrival in the ER

secondary_outcome.description: Effects on vital parameters (e.g. HR, ECG, BP, SpO2) are registered.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from randomization (prehospital) until arrival in the ER, an expected average of 45min

secondary_outcome.description: Tolerability outcome measures include the Bedside Shivering Assessment Scale (BSAS) and a 10 point visual analog scale to assess "feeling cold" and "shivering".
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from randomization (prehospital) until arrival in the ER, an expected average of 45min

secondary_outcome.description: Safety outcome measures include the analysis of (severe) adverse events (e.g. bleeding complications, cardiac decompensation), dose of co-medication needed (e.g. antihypertensives, diuretics, anti-shivering medication), number of patients with oral temperature < 36°C and safety laboratory (Na, K, creatinine, urea, GFR, CK, CK-MB, troponin T, glucose, blood count, INR, aPTT, TT, NT-ProBNP and D-dimer)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from randomization (prehospital) until first neuroimaging (ER), an expected average of 80min

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
